journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Flammability and thermal degradation studies of PVA/rice husk composites

contrib-group.aff: Department of Chemistry, Kurukshetra University, Kurukshetra, India.

author-notes.corresp: Sanjiv Arora, Department of Chemistry, Kurukshetra University, Kurukshetra 136119, India Email: sanjivkuk@yahoo.co.in

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Biodegradable poly(vinyl alcohol)/rice husk (PVA/RH) unplasticized composites are prepared by blending 10 wt%, 20 wt%, and 30 wt% of RH with PVA via solvent-casting technique. Composites are also prepared using boric acid as cross-linking agent. Tensile properties of PVA improved, though slightly, on adding RH and boric acid. Flammability of composites is evaluated using limiting oxygen index (LOI) and Underwriters Laboratory test (UL 94), while thermal stability is determined by employing TG/DTA. Thermal stability of PVA increases on adding RH and boric acid. PVA/RH composite with only 10 wt% RH loading passes HB rating (UL 94) and LOI values increase from 20.5% to 23.5% for 30 wt% RH loading. Better flame retardancy of PVA/RH composites is explained on the basis of ‘heat shielding’ and ‘barrier’ theories. Besides, degradation activation energy calculated by model-free methods favors the flammability data. Silica present in RH is the core substance responsible for the improved flame retardancy of PVA.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The prospective of using biodegradable polymers, more particularly biocomposites synthesized from agro-resources, has been well recognized.1–3 Poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA) is one of the most studied and promising inexpensive biodegradable polymeric materials for the production of biocomposites. It is widely used because of many desirable characteristics such as good film forming capability, flexibility, non-toxicity, adhesive properties, and high-tensile strength.1–6

Lignocellulosic materials such as wood, hemp, and jute are well known as reinforcing agents used in polymer industry to reduce the cost and effecting the improvements in the mechanical properties. Rice husk (RH), a lignocellulosic agricultural biomass, is generated in large quantities in India as a major by-product in rice milling industry.7 The average composition of RH on dry basis is: ash 20%, lignin 22%, cellulose 38%, and hemicellulose 20%.8 Scanning electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, and chemical analysis9–11 reveal that RH is a fibrous material and on burning produces porous ash (RHA) mainly amorphous silica (>90%). The utilization of RH in polymer industry as a lignocellulosic reinforcement is yet to be fully discovered. There are many reports in literature which deal with blends of PVA with starch, cellulose, silica, clay, and cellulose fibers.12–17 It is thought that RH may serve as a better cheap alternative to these. Dai18 has reported the mechanical properties of uncross-linked RH sheets using PVA as an adhesive, whereas, thermal and flammability behaviors have not yet been studied.

Recently, Zhao et al.19 have reported higher thermal stability and low flammability for RH-filled high-density polyethylene (PE) composites, but the mechanical properties of these materials are not yet reported. In addition, there are some reports20–23 which deal with the mechanical properties and other aspects of RH-reinforced PE, poly(propylene) (PP), and poly(vinyl chloride) composites. In the light of above, it is proposed to investigate whether the addition of RH to any polymeric system may also increase the flammability and thermal stability of the composite owing to thermally stable silica present in RH.

Further, superior mechanical strength, which is the key requirement, can be improved using cross-linking agents such as boric acid, borax, formaldehyde, and glutaraldehyde.1,2,5,6 Among them, boric acid is environment-friendly and good for the growth of plants.6

Dynamic thermogravimetry (TG), derivative thermogravimetry (DTG), differential thermal analysis (DTA), limiting oxygen index (LOI), and Underwriters Laboratory test (UL 94) are the most frequently used techniques to examine the thermal and flammability behaviors of the polymeric materials. Thermal degradation kinetics is helpful for understanding the mechanism of polymer degradation and action of additives, using model-free multiple heating rate methods.24,25

In this investigation, PVA/RH blends were cast via solvent-casting method. Thermal stability of samples was checked using simultaneous thermal analysis (TG/DTA) techniques followed by model-free kinetics. The flammability behavior of samples was observed by means of LOI and UL 94 testing.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: PVA (molecular weight = 70,000–1,00,000) and boric acid were supplied by Himedia (India). RH (variety: Haryana Basmati Collection 19 (HBC 19)), collected from Fatehabad, Haryana, India, was first sun dried and then ground to powder using steel grinder. Powdered RH thus obtained was passed through 75 mesh sieve. Distilled water was used. All other materials were used as such without any further purification.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: A series of PVA/RH films were prepared by solution-casting method by varying the contents of RH from 0 to 30 wt%. PVA (5% (w/v)) was dissolved in hot water (80°C); a calculated amount of RH was added to PVA solution and stirred for 6 h. The solution was then cooled to room temperature and films were cast into clean PP dishes. After drying the solution at room temperature for 72 h, the films were removed from the dishes. Hereafter, the composites will be named in the following manner: PVA/RH10, PVA/RH20, PVA/RH30, according to the weight percentage of RH i.e., 10 wt%, 20 wt%, and 30 wt%, respectively. Also, cross-linked PVA/RH/B films (at 10–30 wt% RH) were similarly prepared by adding boric acid (3 wt% of PVA) aqueous solution to PVA/RH solution (80°C) with vigorous stirring for 10 min, followed by air drying at room temperature for 72 h. Finally, all the films were vacuum dried at 80°C for 6 h to ensure complete removal of absorbed moisture and stored in air tight polyethylene bags until further testing.

sec.title: Limiting oxygen index
sec.p:
LOI values of samples were measured according to ASTM D 2863 using an S.A. Associates’s PLATON oxygen index apparatus. The specimens used for the test were of dimensions 100 × 6 × 2 mm3. LOI values are defined by the following equation:
where [O2] and [N2] represent the oxygen and nitrogen concentrations, respectively.

sec.title: UL 94 testing
sec.p:
The flame spread rates of all the samples were investigated by the horizontal burning (HB) test according to the UL 94 test standards. The specimens used for the test were of dimensions 125 × 13 × 2 mm3. Five tests were conducted for each sample. The flame spread or burning rate (mm/min) was calculated using the following equation:
where t1 is the burning time from the beginning to 25 mm and t the burning time from the beginning to 100 mm benchmark. The sample is horizontally mounted on the stand and flame applied to the free end of the specimen for 30 s. The time for the flame front to move between the benchmarks is measured. The sample is classified as HB rating if its burning rate does not exceed 75 mm/min or self-extinguish before 100 mm benchmark.

sec.title: Tensile strength
sec.p: The tensile properties of the PVA films were measured with a Universal testing machine. The test specimens were in the form of dumbbells according to ASTM D 638 and conditioned at 50% relative humidity, 25°C for 24 h. The cross-head speed was 10 mm/min. The reported data are the averages of five measurements.

sec.title: Thermal analysis
sec.p: Simultaneous thermal analysis (TG/DTA) of the samples was conducted under flowing nitrogen atmosphere (50 mLmin−1) at a heating rate of 20°C min−1 using Perkin Elmer, Diamond TG/DTA analyzer. Thermograms of three samples, namely PVA, PVA/RH30, and PVA/RH30/B, were also carried out at 5°C min−1 and 10°C min−1 to meet the requirement of multiple heating rate kinetic analysis. Dried alumina powder (α-Al2O3) was employed as a reference material using ceramic sample holder for taking thermograms.

sec.title: Tensile properties
sec.p:
Tensile strength and percentage elongation at break were measured for the PVA blends, as given in Table 1. Owing to the hydrophilic nature of PVA and RH, it was expected that tensile strength may improve on adding RH to PVA. But it was not so, as tensile strength increased only slightly for PVA/RH10 with an edge for PVA/RH/B samples, while it was not even that much for PVA/RH20 and PVA/RH30 compared to virgin PVA, perhaps due to agglomeration of RH particles in the case of the latter. Boric acid might have formed an intramolecular cross-linking with covalent bond type or an intermolecular cross-linking with hydrogen bond type in PVA resin.26 The percentage of elongation of composites decreases with the increase of the RH contents, which may be attributed to the rigid nature of RH. However, on adding boric acid, films become brittle, resulting in the decrease of elongation. Component of error is unusually towards a higher side. Table 1.
Tensile strengths of PVA and PVA/RH composites
Sample PVA PVA/RH10 PVA/RH20 PVA/RH30 PVA/RH10/B PVA/RH20/B PVA/RH30/B
Tensile strength (MPa) 23.1 ± 1.0 23.9 ± 0.9 22.0 ± 1.2 20.2 ± 1.3 24.5 ± 1.0 23.9 ± 0.8 23.3 ± 0.8
Percentage elongation 25 ± 2 16 ± 2 10 ± 2 7 ± 2 6 ± 1 4 ± 1 3 ± 1

sec.title: Thermal studies
sec.p:
Figures 1–3 represent the thermograms (TG, DTG, and DTA) of all samples at heating rate 20°C min−1. It is well documented12,27,28 that the degradation of PVA obeys a two-step mechanism, as confirmed by the DTG curve (Figure 3). TG curves of all the samples show a slight weight loss around 150°C, which is attributed to the loss of physically absorbed water. Figure 1.
(a) TG curves of PVA/RH composites at a heating rate of 20°C min−1 under flowing nitrogen atmosphere and (b) DTG curves of RH at a heating rate of 20°C min−1 under flowing nitrogen atmosphere. Figure 2.
TG curves of PVA/RH/B composites at a heating rate of 20°C min−1 under flowing nitrogen atmosphere. Figure 3.
DTG and DTA curves of PVA/RH composites at a heating rate of 20°C min−1 under flowing nitrogen atmosphere.

In case of virgin PVA, weight loss in the first step (285–400°C) results from the dehydration and depolymerization of PVA accompanied by the polyene formation.29 During the second step (400°C onwards), the residue of the first stage undergoes intramolecular cyclization, producing some organic volatiles.29 Thermal degradation of RH is a much complex process due to its composite nature.30 There occurs a considerably small weight loss around 190°C corresponding to hemicellulose degradation (Figure 1(b)). However, the major weight loss occurs between around 250°C and 400°C, which corresponds to degradation of celluloses. Lignin degrades throughout the temperature range 250–600°C.3,30,31

Thermal stability of PVA/RH is more than PVA. For example, the onset decomposition temperature (To), DTG maxima, and DTA peak point of PVA/RH30 are higher by 23°C, 50°C, and 19°C, respectively (Table 2). Probably, higher stability of PVA/RH is due to higher stability of RH than PVA (~17°C). Ash, cellulose, and lignin present in RH are responsible for better initial stability. Better stability of PVA/RH at higher temperatures is attributed to silica present in RH, which forms a thermal barrier and significantly delays the thermal degradation of composite. Maximum degradation rate (Max. deg. rate) for virgin PVA is equal to 28 (% min−1), while it is 17.6% min−1 for PVA/RH30. It means that PVA/RH composites degrade slowly in comparison to virgin PVA film. PVA/RH/B films degrade even slower than PVA/RH (Table 2). Table 2.
Thermal degradation characteristics of PVA, RH, and PVA/RH composites at a heating rate of 20°C min−1
Sample To (°C) DTG maxima (°C) DTA maxima (°C)/ nature of peak Maximum degradation rate (% min−1) Weight residue (%) left at
300°C 400°C 600°C
RH 285.6 315.6 295.8/endo 19.0 81.6 39.4 31.3
PVA 268.5 290.6 299.7/endo 28.0 58.3 19.4 5.4
PVA/RH10 272.5 314.3 304.0/endo 20.2 74.8 16.4 7.4
PVA/RH20 274.1 341.0 310.1/endo 17.5 78.9 20.5 9.1
PVA/RH30 291.7 341.1 318.5/endo 17.6 85.2 21.7 10.2
PVA/RH10/B 295.6 330.0 327.8/endo 21.5 88.2 24.4 7.0
PVA/RH20/B 301.9 352.1 339.5/endo 18.7 91.7 29.9 8.0
PVA/RH30/B 305.2 353.0 340.8/endo 16.3 90.5 34.0 11.6
Note: To denotes the onset degradation temperature.

To, DTA maxima, and DTG maxima for PVA/RH30/B film are elevated by 36.7(13.5)°C, 41.1(22.3)°C, and 62.4(11.9)°C, respectively, compared to PVA(PVA/RH30) films. Weight loss at the completion of dehydration process (400°C) for PVA/RH30/B is 66% in comparison to 80.6% and 78.3% for PVA and PVA/RH30, respectively (Table 2). Thus, boric acid enhances the thermal stability of PVA/RH/B films by suppressing the weight loss during dehydration step in line with the findings of Gao et al.32 However, Blasi et al.33 and Wang et al.34 have stated that boric acid catalyzes the dehydration reactions.
Based on DTA maxima, onset degradation temperature, and DTG maxima values, the following stability order is suggested: PVA/RH/B > PVA/RH > PVA.

sec.title: Kinetic studies
sec.p:
We have chosen three samples i.e., neat PVA, PVA/RH30, and PVA/RH30/B for comparative kinetic studies. Thermograms were observed at three different linear heating rates and are shown in Figure 4(a)–(c). Figure 4.
TG curves of: (a) PVA, (b) PVA/RH30, and (c) PVA/RH30/B composites at three different heating rates.

The main equations of the kinetic methods used in this research to study thermal degradation of PVA samples are summarized in Table 3. In these equations, β is the heating rate, t the time, T the temperature, Tm the maxima of DTG curve, n the reaction order, R the universal gas constant, A the pre-exponential factor, α the degree of conversion, and E the activation energy. Table 3.
Formulae of kinetic methods used for calculating activation energy in this study
Method Final equation Plots
O–F–W29,30
Log β against 1/T
Friedman28
ln(β(dα/dT)) against 1/T
Coats–Redfern (modified)31,32
ln(β/T2) against 1/T

As an example, the Friedman35 iso-conversional plot for PVA/RH30/B is shown in Figure 5(a), while Figure 5(b) and (c) show the specific results of application of O–F–W36,37 and modified Coats–Redfern38,39 methods using PVA and PVA/RH30. The evaluated degradation activation energies at varying degrees of conversion are summarized in Table 4. Only those values are shown in the table whose plots have produced good regression coefficients (correlation coefficient >0.95); the rest are neglected for the sake of accurate comparison. Figure 5.
Iso-conversional plots of: (a) Friedman, (b) O–F–W, and (c) Coats–Redfern for PVA/RH30/B, PVA, and PVA/RH30, respectively. Table 4.
Degradation activation energy values calculated using model-free methods
Degree of conversion, α Activation energy (kJ mol−1)
PVA PVA/RH30 PVA/RH30/B
Friedman O–F–W Coats–Redfern Friedman O–F–W Coats–Redfern Friedman O–F–W Coats–Redfern
0.07 210.1 176.4 176.7 129.0 121.6 119.0 203.9 334.7 342.5
0.08 244.7 183.8 184.5 121.1 121.7 122.5 165.4 223.0 225.3
0.09 196.9 186.3 187.1 122.1 124.7 122.1 142.4 196.9 197.8
0.10 183.9 187.6 188.4 128.5 124.7 122.0 167.0 179.6 179.6
0.15 166.2 184.2 184.7 138.8 128.0 125.3 160.7 170.1 169.4
0.20 153.2 177.4 177.5 145.0 132.6 130.1 160.6 166.0 165.0
0.25 140.6 170.5 170.2 143.9 137.2 134.7 164.2 164.4 163.1
0.30 124.6 163.5 162.8 144.0 139.8 137.4 166.9 164.8 163.4
0.35 111.9 155.9 154.7 143.5 141.6 139.3 171.9 165.9 164.5
0.40 92.9 147.8 146.1 144.5 142.8 140.4 174.6 168.2 166.8
0.45 75.3 138.3 136.2 146.5 143.8 141.5 182.4 170.6 169.3
0.50 55.0 127.4 124.6 148.6 145.2 142.8 194.5 174.8 173.6
0.55 43.6 114.2 110.6 155.3 146.7 144.3 208.5 181.9 180.9
0.60 33.8 100.5 96.1 160.5 149.7 147.3 239.8 192.2 191.6
0.65 43.1 87.0 81.8 175.0 153.4 151.0 324.4 215.9 216.4
0.70 65.8 78.8 73.0 201.9 160.9 158.9 471.8 321.2 326.9

It can be seen from Table 4 that E values calculated using Coats–Redfern (modified) are in well agreement with those of O–F–W.31 Initial degradation E values for virgin PVA are 210.1, 176.4, and 176.7 kJ mol−1, as calculated using Friedman, O–F–W, and Coats–Redfern (modified) approaches, respectively. After a small increment up to α = 0.1, E values show a regular decrease with the increase in degree of conversion. However, Friedman generates comparatively large decrease in values of activation energy. For example, the value found by Friedman method is 33.8 at α = 0.6 in comparison to 96.1 and 100.5 kJ mol−1 by Coats–Redfern (modified) and O–F–W, respectively. Zhou et al.12 have reported an E value of 124.6 kJ mol−1 (at α = 0.5) for virgin PVA using O–F–W approach, which matches well with our value i.e., 127.4 kJ mol−1 (Table 5). Table 5.
LOI and UL94 data of PVA samples
Sample HB test LOI (%)
Rate of burning (mm/min) Flame characteristics Status
PVA virgin 81.8 Drip, no charring and CB Fail 20.5
PVA/RH10 69.2 Drip, CB Pass, HB 21.5
PVA/RH20 60.0 Drip, CB Pass, HB 22.3
PVA/RH30 52.9 No drip, CB Pass, HB 23.5
PVA/RH10/B 65.7 No drip, charring with noise and CB Pass, HB 21.8
PVA/RH20/B 57.7 No drip, charring with noise and CB Pass, HB 22.7
PVA/RH30/B 50.0 No drip, charring with noise and CB Pass, HB 23.8
Note: CB stands for completely burned.

Contrary to PVA, the case of E values for PVA/RH30 increases (except at α = 0.07 for Friedman) while moving towards higher degree of conversions. E values for PVA/RH30 are relatively smaller than PVA up to α = 0.2/0.4 (Friedman/O–F–W and Coats–Redfern). This behavior is may be due to reason that initial E values in case of PVA/RH30 correspond to degradation of less stable hemicelluloses present in RH.30,31 However, above this point (α = 0.2/0.4), PVA/RH30 composites exhibit larger E values than PVA. The respective values calculated using Friedman, Coats–Redfern, and O–F–W methods at α = 0.5 are 148.6(55.0), 142.8(124.6), and 145.2(127.4) kJ mol−1, for PVA/RH30(PVA), indicating higher thermal stability of RH in comparison to PVA.

PVA/RH30/B film presents comparatively higher E values than PVA and PVA/RH30. E values first regularly decrease up to α = 0.2, showing an increase with the progress of degradation reaction till the end. Boric acid cross-links PVA effectively and halts the dehydration of PVA. At half-conversion, E values for PVA/RH30/B (PVA/RH30) are 194.5(148.6), 173.6(142.8), and 174.8(145.2) kJ mol−1, as calculated by Friedman, Coats–Redfern, and O–F–W methods, respectively. E values for cross-linked composites show an adequate increase after completion of half the reaction. This is mainly due to the formation of silica and boron-trioxide char layer, which resists the further degradation of the composite. It can be concluded that RH and boric acid are good substances to increase the degradation activation energy and the specific order thus obtained is: PVA/RH/B > PVA/RH > PVA.

sec.title: Flammability studies
sec.p: LOI values and UL 94 results of PVA and PVA/RH films are given in Table 5. Neat PVA is highly combustible, and its LOI value is only 20.5%. LOI values of PVA/RH films increase with the increase in RH content. LOI value of PVA/RH 30 is as high as 23.5%. It was also observed in UL 94 testing that PVA films with loading level greater than 20 wt% burn without dripping. This is entirely a different behavior in comparison to the neat PVA which badly drips during the test.

Flame retardation of PVA/RH composites can be understood via ‘heat shielding’ and ‘barrier’ theories.40,41 Flame-retardant character is traced to the response of a carbonaceous and inorganic char layer, resulting from the combustion of PVA and RH, respectively,16,17,19,30 which shields the remaining part of the composite film from heat and oxygen, leading to slow spread of flame. Being porous materials, RH and RHA contribute the films to avoid dripping.8–10 It is worth stating that RH contains the highest percentage of silica among all lignocellulosic fibers. Therefore, it can be concluded that having good amount of silica, RH will lead among all the lignocellulosic materials as a flame-retardant reinforcement.

Boric acid is a typical flame retardant and its addition to PVA/RH shows a positive but smaller effect on the LOI and HB rate. LOI and burning rate are slightly improved (Table 5). This finding is in good agreement with literature report28 that boric acid has little effect on flame spread. In addition, relatively higher char yield is produced in the case of samples containing boric acid.

Generally, it is assumed that boric acid works via dehydration mechanism. However, this mechanism is not applicable here, as shown by weight loss and activation energy data given in preceding subsections. Hydroxyl groups of boric acid form strong intermolecular hydrogen bonding with hydroxyl group on PVA. Importantly, hydroxyl group on PVA is the easy degradable site, which upon action of heat releases water followed by depolymerization process.28 Hence, boric acid increases the flame retardancy of PVA by protecting hydroxyl group on PVA via cross-linking reactions.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The PVA/RH composite films were successfully prepared via solution-casting method. Tensile strength values are almost alike for PVA/RH and PVA. However, cross-linked PVA/RH/B composites have shown slightly higher tensile strength than PVA/RH and PVA. It can be attributed to the formation of intermolecular hydrogen bonding between hydroxyl groups of boric acid and PVA. Simultaneous TG/DTA experiments and kinetic studies concluded that the PVA/RH/B and PVA/RH composites are thermally more stable than virgin PVA.

Flame retardancies of PVA/RH/B and PVA/RH composites are more than PVA, as evident from LOI and UL 94 testings. On burning, RH produces ash which mainly contains silica. This ash shields the composite from heat and obstructs the oxygen supply. Boric acid resists the dehydration of PVA by protecting the most easy degradable site in PVA i.e., hydroxyl group, through the formation of intermolecular hydrogen bonding with its hydroxyl group. This is well proved in TG and non-isothermal iso-conversional kinetic studies showing lesser weight loss and higher activation energy values corresponding to dehydration stage in the case of cross-linked samples.
Thus, RH can be applied to prepare low-cost, thermally stable, and low-flammable PVA/RH composites which favorably compare with the existing one in use.

The authors also thank Mr JK Bihani of Galaxy Plywood Industries (P) Ltd., Yamunagar, Haryana, for his help in mechanical testing.
